author: BVM Sportsdesk
title: Capitals' Ryan Leonard, Wild's Zeev Buium make 2025 Hobey Baker final 10
text:
Capitals’ Ryan Leonard, Wild’s Zeev Buium make 2025 Hobey Baker final 10
The NCAA has revealed the top 10 finalists for the 2025 Hobey Baker Award, showcasing standout players including Washington Capitals prospect Ryan Leonard and Minnesota Wild prospect Zeev Buium. The award honors the top men's NCAA player, with this year's finalists lacking any draft-eligible players, breaking a two-year streak. Leonard has made a strong impact with 29 goals and 18 assists this season at Boston College, while Buium has excelled with 10 goals and 32 assists at the University of Denver. Other notable finalists include Isaac Howard and goaltender Alex Tracy, who leads with an impressive .946 save percentage.
By the Numbers- Ryan Leonard: 29 goals, 18 assists, 47 points in 35 games
- Zeev Buium: 10 goals, 32 assists, 42 points in 36 games
- Isaac Howard: 24 goals, 23 assists, 47 points in 35 games
- Alex Tracy: 25 wins, .946 save percentage, 5 shutouts in 36 games
The absence of draft-eligible players among the finalists raises questions about the criteria and evolving landscape of NCAA hockey, especially after recent winners were all draft-eligible. This shift may signal a different focus among top college players and their development paths.
State of Play- The Hobey Baker winner will break a two-year trend of draft-eligible players winning the award.
- Leonard and Buium are among several prospects making significant contributions at the collegiate level.
As the season progresses, attention will be on how these finalists perform in upcoming games, impacting their chances for the Hobey Baker Award. Their performances could also influence their respective team's decisions regarding their futures in the NHL.
Bottom LineThis year's Hobey Baker finalists highlight a shift towards recognizing established collegiate talent, with notable prospects poised to influence the future of NHL rosters. Monitoring their continued success will be critical for evaluating their readiness for professional play.
